formulas.name: One-Rep Max (1RM) Estimation (Epley Formula)
formulas.description: Estimates the maximum weight an individual can lift for one repetition, representing their maximal strength for that lift, based on a sub-maximal lift.

variables.name: Reps
variables.description: Number of repetitions performed to failure (typically 2-10 reps)

formulas.notes: Numerous 1RM estimation formulas exist (e.g., Brzycki, Lombardi, O'Conner). This is an estimation; actual 1RM may vary. Represents a 'maximal' effort for a given lift.

formulas.name: Training Volume (per exercise/set)
formulas.description: Quantifies the total work performed for a specific exercise or set.
formulas.notes: Can be summed across multiple exercises for total session or weekly volume. Essential for tracking progressive overload.

formulas.name: Percentage of One-Rep Max (%1RM)
formulas.description: Calculates the target weight to be lifted based on a percentage of the estimated 1RM, used for prescribing training intensity.

variables.name: %Target
variables.description: Desired intensity as a percentage (e.g., 0.80 for 80%)

formulas.notes: Different percentages correspond to different training adaptations (e.g., 85%+ for strength, 60-80% for hypertrophy, <60% for endurance).

formulas.name: Reps in Reserve (RIR)
formulas.description: A subjective measure of how many more repetitions a person *could* have performed at the end of a set before reaching momentary muscular failure. RIR 0 represents a maximal effort for that set.
formulas.formula: Subjective Scale (e.g., RIR 0 = no reps left, RIR 3 = 3 reps left)
formulas.notes: Used to autoregulate training intensity. RIR 0 signifies a 'maximal' effort for the set, while higher RIR values indicate a 'minimal' or submaximal effort relative to failure.

formulas.name: Relative Strength
formulas.description: Measures an individual's strength in relation to their body weight, often used to compare strength across different body sizes.
formulas.notes: Higher values indicate greater relative strength, important in sports like gymnastics or climbing.

formulas.name: Strength-Endurance Index
formulas.description: Measures the ability to sustain a percentage of maximal strength over multiple repetitions.
formulas.formula: $$Strength-Endurance Index = \frac{Number of Reps at \%1RM}{Max Reps Expected at \%1RM}$$

variables.name: Number of Reps at %1RM
variables.description: Actual repetitions performed at a given percentage of 1RM

variables.name: Max Reps Expected at %1RM
variables.description: Theoretical maximal repetitions at that %1RM (from a rep max chart)

formulas.notes: Used to assess and train the ability to perform repeated efforts at a given intensity.

formulas.name: Average Speed
formulas.description: Calculates the average rate at which an object or person covers a distance. Maximal speed is the highest average speed achieved over a short distance.
formulas.notes: Used for sprint times, running pace, etc. 'Maximal speed' refers to the highest speed attained, typically over 10-30m flying sprints.

formulas.name: Average Acceleration
formulas.description: Calculates the rate of change of velocity over a period of time. Maximal acceleration is the highest rate of change in velocity.
formulas.notes: Important for understanding the starting phase of a sprint or change of direction. 'Maximal acceleration' is the peak acceleration achieved during a sprint start.

formulas.name: Stride Length
formulas.description: The distance covered by one complete gait cycle (e.g., from one foot strike to the next foot strike of the same foot).
formulas.notes: Optimizing stride length and frequency is key for running efficiency and speed. Often measured with specialized sensors or video analysis.

formulas.name: Stride Frequency (Cadence)
formulas.description: The number of steps or strides taken per unit of time.

variables.name: Stride Frequency
variables.description: Number of strides per minute or second

formulas.notes: Often measured as steps per minute (SPM) or strides per minute. Higher cadence is often associated with better running economy at higher speeds.

formulas.name: Agility Test Time
formulas.description: Measures the time taken to complete a specific agility drill, indicating an individual's ability to change direction quickly and efficiently. The goal is to achieve the minimal time.
formulas.formula: $$Time_{Agility} = Time_{End} - Time_{Start}$$ (measured with timing gates or stopwatch)

variables.name: $Time_{Agility}$
variables.description: Total time to complete the agility drill (minimal time desired)

variables.name: $Time_{Start}$
variables.description: Time at the start of the drill

variables.name: $Time_{End}$
variables.description: Time at the end of the drill

formulas.notes: Common tests include the T-Test, Pro Agility Shuttle (5-10-5), or Illinois Agility Test. Lower times indicate better agility and coordination.

formulas.name: Y-Balance Test Reach Distance
formulas.description: Measures dynamic balance and neuromuscular control by assessing maximum reach in three directions. The goal is to achieve maximal reach distances.
formulas.formula: Measured directly in centimeters or inches for anterior, posteromedial, and posterolateral directions.
formulas.notes: Often normalized to limb length. Used to identify asymmetries and risk of injury. Not a formula, but a key measurement where 'maximal' performance is desired.

formulas.name: Star Excursion Balance Test (SEBT) Composite Score
formulas.description: A comprehensive measure of dynamic balance, assessing reach in eight directions. The goal is to achieve a maximal composite score.
formulas.formula: $$Composite Score = \frac{Sum of 3 trials in all 8 directions}{24 \times Leg Length} \times 100$$

variables.name: Sum of 3 trials in all 8 directions
variables.description: Total reach distance from 3 trials in each of 8 directions

formulas.notes: Higher scores indicate better dynamic balance. Used for injury screening and performance assessment.

formulas.name: Maximum Heart Rate (MHR) Estimation (Tanaka Formula)
formulas.description: Estimates the maximum number of times your heart can beat per minute during intense exercise. This is a crucial 'maximal' physiological parameter.
formulas.notes: This formula is often considered more accurate than '220 - Age'. MHR is used as a basis for calculating training zones. An individual's true MHR can only be determined by a maximal exercise test.

formulas.name: Resting Heart Rate (RHR)
formulas.description: The number of times your heart beats per minute while at complete rest. A lower RHR typically indicates better cardiovascular fitness ('minimal' heart rate).
formulas.formula: Measured directly by counting beats per minute upon waking or after prolonged rest.
formulas.notes: A key indicator of cardiovascular health and recovery. Consistently elevated RHR can be a sign of fatigue or illness.

formulas.name: Heart Rate Reserve (HRR)
formulas.description: The difference between your maximum heart rate and your resting heart rate, representing the range of heart rates available for exercise.
formulas.notes: A key component of the Karvonen Formula for calculating target heart rate zones.

formulas.name: Target Heart Rate (THR) (Karvonen Formula)
formulas.description: Calculates the target heart rate for a specific exercise intensity, taking into account resting heart rate for a more personalized zone.

variables.name: %Intensity
variables.description: Desired intensity as a percentage (e.g., 0.60 for 60%)

formulas.notes: Different intensity percentages correspond to different training effects (e.g., 50-70% for aerobic base, 70-85% for cardiovascular fitness).

formulas.name: VO2 Max Estimation (1.5 Mile Run Test)
formulas.description: Estimates maximal oxygen uptake based on the distance covered in a 1.5-mile run. This is a key 'maximal' physiological capacity.
formulas.notes: Numerous field tests exist (e.g., Cooper 12-minute run, Rockport Walk Test) with different formulas. This is a common estimation for runners. Lab tests are more accurate for true maximal values.

formulas.name: Running Economy
formulas.description: The oxygen cost of running at a given submaximal speed, indicating how efficiently a runner uses oxygen. The goal is to minimize oxygen cost for a given speed.
formulas.formula: Measured via indirect calorimetry during submaximal running, often expressed as mL O2/kg/km.

variables.name: Running Economy
variables.description: Oxygen cost per unit distance or time (minimal cost desired)

formulas.notes: Lower oxygen cost at a given speed indicates better running economy. Not a simple formula for calculation without lab equipment.

formulas.name: Lactate Threshold (LT)
formulas.description: The exercise intensity at which blood lactate begins to accumulate rapidly, indicating a shift from predominantly aerobic to anaerobic metabolism. Represents the maximal sustainable aerobic intensity.
formulas.formula: Determined by measuring blood lactate concentration at increasing exercise intensities (e.g., during a graded exercise test).

variables.name: Lactate Threshold
variables.description: Exercise intensity (e.g., heart rate, power, speed)

formulas.notes: A critical determinant of endurance performance. Often identified as the highest intensity that can be sustained without continuous lactate accumulation.

formulas.name: Ventilatory Thresholds (VT1 & VT2)
formulas.description: Points during exercise where ventilation increases disproportionately to oxygen uptake, indicating shifts in metabolic reliance. VT2 often correlates with the maximal lactate steady state.
formulas.formula: Determined by gas exchange analysis during a graded exercise test (identifying breakpoints in VE/VO2 and VE/VCO2 ratios).

variables.name: VT1 (Aerobic Threshold)
variables.description: Intensity at first disproportionate increase in ventilation

variables.name: VT2 (Anaerobic Threshold / Respiratory Compensation Point)
variables.description: Intensity at second disproportionate increase in ventilation

formulas.notes: Used for precise training zone prescription. Requires specialized lab equipment.

formulas.name: Critical Power / Speed
formulas.description: The highest power output or speed that can be maintained for a prolonged period without continuous fatigue, representing the boundary between heavy and severe exercise domains. This is a 'maximal' sustainable effort.
formulas.formula: Derived from multiple time-to-exhaustion trials at different constant power outputs or speeds, using a linear regression model.
formulas.notes: A robust measure of aerobic capacity and fatigue resistance. Requires multiple maximal effort tests.

formulas.name: Power-to-Weight Ratio (Cycling)
formulas.description: Measures a cyclist's power output relative to their body weight, crucial for climbing performance.
formulas.notes: Higher values indicate better climbing ability. Often expressed for different durations (e.g., 5-second max, 20-minute FTP).

formulas.name: Session RPE (sRPE) Training Load
formulas.description: Quantifies the perceived physiological stress of a training session, combining subjective effort and duration.

variables.name: RPE
variables.description: Rate of Perceived Exertion (0-10 scale, or Borg 6-20 scale)

variables.name: Session Duration
variables.description: Total duration of the training session

formulas.notes: A simple and effective method for monitoring daily training load and tracking fatigue. Can be summed for weekly load.

formulas.name: Training Stress Score (TSS) / Normalized Power (NP) (Cycling/Running)
formulas.description: A proprietary metric (from TrainingPeaks) that quantifies the physiological stress of a workout, accounting for intensity, duration, and individual fitness. Based on power (cycling) or pace (running).

variables.name: Normalized Power (NP)
variables.description: Adjusted power output that accounts for variability

variables.name: Intensity Factor (IF)
variables.description: Ratio of NP to Functional Threshold Power (FTP)

variables.name: FTP
variables.description: Functional Threshold Power (maximal power sustainable for 60 min)

formulas.notes: Similar formulas exist for running (rTSS) based on pace and Functional Threshold Pace (FTPace). Used for precise load management.

formulas.name: Acute Training Load (ATL) / Fatigue
formulas.description: Represents the short-term training stress, often a weighted average of recent daily training loads (e.g., sRPE, TSS).
formulas.formula: $$ATL = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{7} (Load_i \times Weighting_i)}{\sum_{i=1}^{7} Weighting_i}$$ (typically an exponentially weighted moving average)

variables.name: $Load_i$
variables.description: Daily training load (sRPE or TSS) for day 'i'

variables.name: $Weighting_i$
variables.description: Weighting factor for day 'i' (e.g., more recent days weighted higher)

formulas.notes: Reflects how fatigued an athlete is from recent training. A common decay is 7 days.

formulas.name: Chronic Training Load (CTL) / Fitness
formulas.description: Represents the long-term training stress and accumulated fitness, often a weighted average of daily training loads over a longer period.
formulas.formula: $$CTL = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{42} (Load_i \times Weighting_i)}{\sum_{i=1}^{42} Weighting_i}$$ (typically an exponentially weighted moving average)

variables.name: $Load_i$
variables.description: Daily training load (sRPE or TSS) for day 'i'

variables.name: $Weighting_i$
variables.description: Weighting factor for day 'i' (e.g., more recent days weighted higher)

formulas.notes: Reflects an athlete's overall fitness level. A common decay is 42 days.

formulas.name: Training Stress Balance (TSB) / Form
formulas.description: Indicates an athlete's readiness to perform, by comparing long-term fitness to short-term fatigue.
formulas.notes: A positive TSB suggests freshness and readiness for performance, while a negative TSB suggests fatigue and potential for overtraining. The goal is often to optimize TSB for maximal performance at key times.

formulas.name: Acute:Chronic Workload Ratio (ACWR)
formulas.description: Compares recent training load (acute) to chronic training load to assess injury risk and training appropriateness.
formulas.notes: An ACWR between 0.8-1.3 is often considered the 'sweet spot' for optimal training adaptation with reduced injury risk. Values >1.5 are associated with higher injury risk. This helps identify 'minimal' safe increases in workload.

formulas.name: Minimal Effective Dose (MED)
formulas.description: The lowest amount of training stimulus (volume, intensity, frequency) required to elicit a desired adaptation or maintain fitness. This is a conceptual 'minimal' threshold for training.
formulas.formula: Not a single formula; determined empirically through individual trial and error, or based on scientific literature for general guidelines.
formulas.notes: The MED helps prevent overtraining and maximize recovery by avoiding unnecessary training load. It's about finding the 'minimum' required stimulus for progress.

formulas.name: Mechanical Power
formulas.description: The rate at which work is done, or the product of force and velocity. Maximal power is the highest power output achieved.
formulas.notes: Crucial for activities requiring rapid, forceful movements like jumping, throwing, and sprinting. 'Maximal power' is often measured during specific tests like countermovement jumps or Olympic lifts.

formulas.name: Vertical Jump Height (from Flight Time)
formulas.description: Estimates vertical jump height based on the time an individual spends in the air during a jump. The goal is to achieve maximal jump height.
formulas.formula: $$Jump Height = \frac{1}{2} \times g \times (Flight Time / 2)^2$$ (where $g$ is acceleration due to gravity)

variables.name: Jump Height
variables.description: Vertical height of the jump (maximal height desired)

variables.name: Flight Time
variables.description: Total time spent in the air

formulas.notes: A common method using jump mats or video analysis. Higher jump height indicates greater lower body power.

formulas.name: Rate of Force Development (RFD)
formulas.description: Measures how quickly an individual can produce force, indicating explosive strength. Maximal RFD is the highest rate of force increase.

variables.name: $\Delta Time$
variables.description: Change in time over which force is produced

formulas.notes: Typically measured using force plates during isometric or dynamic contractions. Higher RFD means faster force production. 'Maximal RFD' is the peak slope of the force-time curve.

formulas.name: Impulse
formulas.description: The change in momentum of an object, representing the effect of force applied over time. Crucial for understanding explosive movements.
formulas.notes: Often measured from force-time curves during jumps or sprints. Greater impulse leads to greater changes in velocity.

formulas.name: Force-Velocity Profile
formulas.description: Analyzes the relationship between the force an individual can produce and the velocity at which they can produce it. Identifies strengths (e.g., maximal force, maximal velocity, maximal power).
formulas.formula: Derived from multiple lifts/jumps at varying loads, plotting force vs. velocity. Often represented graphically.
formulas.notes: Used to tailor training to improve specific aspects of power (e.g., more force-dominant or velocity-dominant training). Identifies maximal capabilities.

formulas.name: Velocity Loss (VBT)
formulas.description: The percentage decrease in mean propulsive velocity (MPV) from the first repetition to the last repetition in a set. Used to autoregulate training intensity and fatigue.

variables.name: $MPV_{Initial}$
variables.description: Mean propulsive velocity of the first repetition

variables.name: $MPV_{Final}$
variables.description: Mean propulsive velocity of the last repetition

formulas.notes: Used in Velocity-Based Training (VBT) to prescribe sets to a specific fatigue threshold (e.g., stop set at 20% velocity loss). Helps manage 'minimal' fatigue for a given session.

formulas.name: Reaction Time Measurement
formulas.description: The time elapsed between a stimulus and the initiation of a response. The goal is to achieve minimal reaction time.
formulas.formula: Measured directly via specialized equipment (e.g., reaction time testers, timing gates, software).

variables.name: Reaction Time
variables.description: Time from stimulus onset to response initiation (minimal time desired)

formulas.notes: Can be simple (response to a single stimulus) or choice (response to one of several stimuli). Shorter times indicate faster reaction.

formulas.name: Change of Direction Speed Test Time
formulas.description: Measures the time taken to complete a drill involving multiple changes in direction, reflecting agility and turn speed. The goal is to achieve minimal time.
formulas.formula: $$Time_{COD} = Time_{End} - Time_{Start}$$ (measured with timing gates or stopwatch)

variables.name: $Time_{COD}$
variables.description: Total time to complete the change of direction drill (minimal time desired)

variables.name: $Time_{Start}$
variables.description: Time at the start of the drill

variables.name: $Time_{End}$
variables.description: Time at the end of the drill

formulas.notes: Similar to agility tests, but specifically emphasizes the speed of turning and re-acceleration. Examples include 5-0-5 Agility Test or Zig-Zag Run.

formulas.name: Angular Velocity
formulas.description: The rate at which an object rotates or revolves around an axis. Relevant for analyzing body segment rotation during turns. Maximal angular velocity is the highest rate of rotation.
formulas.notes: Often analyzed using motion capture technology to precisely measure joint and limb rotations during turning movements. 'Maximal angular velocity' refers to the peak rotational speed achieved.

formulas.name: Joint Range of Motion (ROM) Measurement
formulas.description: Measures the degrees of movement available at a specific joint. The goal is often to achieve maximal ROM without discomfort.
formulas.formula: Measured directly using a goniometer or inclinometer.
formulas.notes: Assessments often compare passive (external force) vs. active (muscle contraction) ROM. Important for injury prevention and movement efficiency. 'Minimal' ROM would indicate a restriction.

formulas.name: Sit-and-Reach Test Score
formulas.description: Measures hamstring and lower back flexibility. The goal is to achieve a maximal reach score.
formulas.formula: Measured directly in centimeters or inches from a standardized baseline.

variables.name: Score
variables.description: Distance reached beyond (or short of) the toes (maximal score desired)

formulas.notes: A higher score (further reach) indicates greater flexibility.

formulas.name: Body Mass Index (BMI)
formulas.description: A simple index of weight-for-height that is commonly used to classify underweight, overweight and obesity in adults. Can indicate 'minimal' healthy weight or 'maximal' unhealthy weight.
formulas.notes: Does not differentiate between fat and muscle mass. A high BMI can be due to high muscle mass. Use with caution for athletes. Classifications define 'minimal' and 'maximal' healthy ranges.

formulas.name: Waist-to-Hip Ratio (WHR)
formulas.description: Measures the ratio of waist circumference to hip circumference, indicating body fat distribution and associated health risks. The goal is often to maintain a 'minimal' WHR for health.

variables.name: Waist Circumference
variables.description: Circumference at the narrowest point of the waist

variables.name: Hip Circumference
variables.description: Circumference at the widest part of the hips

formulas.notes: Higher ratios (especially >0.90 for men, >0.85 for women) are associated with increased health risks. Lower WHR is generally desirable.

formulas.name: Body Fat Percentage (General Calculation)
formulas.description: The proportion of total body weight that is fat. Often estimated via various methods. Athletes may aim for a 'minimal' healthy body fat percentage for performance.

variables.name: Fat Mass
variables.description: Total weight of fat in the body

formulas.notes: Fat mass can be estimated using skinfold calipers (requiring specific equations like Jackson-Pollock), Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA), or more accurately with DEXA scans. The formula here is conceptual. 'Minimal' healthy body fat is crucial for performance and health.

formulas.name: Lean Body Mass (LBM)
formulas.description: The weight of the body's non-fat components (muscle, bone, organs, water). The goal is often to maximize LBM for strength and power sports.
formulas.formula: $$LBM = Total Body Weight - Fat Mass$$ OR $$LBM = Total Body Weight \times (1 - \frac{Body Fat \%}{100})$$

variables.name: LBM
variables.description: Lean Body Mass (maximal LBM desired for certain goals)

variables.name: Fat Mass
variables.description: Total weight of fat in the body

formulas.notes: Important for calculating basal metabolic rate and tracking muscle gain/loss.

formulas.name: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) (Mifflin-St Jeor Equation)
formulas.description: Estimates the number of calories your body burns at rest to maintain basic physiological functions. This is the 'minimal' energy expenditure for survival.
formulas.formula: For Men: $$BMR = (10 \times Weight_{kg}) + (6.25 \times Height_{cm}) - (5 \times Age_{years}) + 5$$ For Women: $$BMR = (10 \times Weight_{kg}) + (6.25 \times Height_{cm}) - (5 \times Age_{years}) - 161$$
formulas.notes: Considered one of the most accurate predictive equations for BMR. Other equations exist (e.g., Harris-Benedict).

formulas.name: Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE)
formulas.description: Estimates the total number of calories burned in a day, including BMR and physical activity. This represents the 'maximal' energy expenditure for a given activity level.

variables.name: Activity Factor
variables.description: Multiplier based on activity level (e.g., Sedentary: 1.2, Lightly Active: 1.375, Moderately Active: 1.55, Very Active: 1.725, Extra Active: 1.9)

formulas.notes: Used to determine caloric intake for weight maintenance, loss, or gain.

formulas.name: Caloric Deficit/Surplus
formulas.description: The difference between calories consumed and calories expended, determining weight change. A 'deficit' is a negative value, 'surplus' is positive.
formulas.notes: A deficit leads to weight loss, a surplus to weight gain. Approximately 3500 calories = 1 lb of body fat.

formulas.name: Macronutrient Grams (e.g., Protein)
formulas.description: Calculates the target grams of a specific macronutrient based on total caloric intake and desired percentage. Can be used to determine 'minimal' or 'maximal' intake for specific goals.

variables.name: $\%Calories_{Macro}$
variables.description: Desired percentage of calories from that macronutrient (e.g., 0.30 for 30%)

variables.name: $Calories Per Gram_{Macro}$
variables.description: Caloric value per gram (Protein: 4 kcal/g, Carbs: 4 kcal/g, Fat: 9 kcal/g)

formulas.notes: Used for precise dietary planning to support fitness goals. For example, a 'minimal' protein intake might be 0.8g/kg body weight, while a 'maximal' might be 2.2g/kg or more for muscle gain.

formulas.name: Respiratory Quotient (RQ)
formulas.description: The ratio of carbon dioxide produced to oxygen consumed, indicating the type of fuel (carbohydrates vs. fat) being metabolized. Ranges from 0.7 (pure fat) to 1.0 (pure carbohydrate).
formulas.notes: RQ values closer to 1.0 indicate carbohydrate metabolism, closer to 0.7 indicate fat metabolism. Measured via indirect calorimetry. Represents the 'maximal' or 'minimal' reliance on a specific fuel source.

formulas.name: Heart Rate Variability (HRV)
formulas.description: The physiological phenomenon of the variation in the time interval between consecutive heartbeats. While complex to calculate directly, it's a critical metric. Higher HRV generally indicates better recovery ('maximal' readiness), lower HRV indicates stress ('minimal' readiness).
formulas.formula: Calculated by specialized devices/software using various statistical methods (e.g., RMSSD, SDNN, LF/HF ratio).
formulas.notes: Higher HRV generally indicates a well-recovered and parasympathetic-dominant state, while lower HRV can signal fatigue, stress, or overtraining. Often tracked daily to observe trends and identify 'minimal' recovery states.

formulas.name: Orthostatic Heart Rate Test
formulas.description: Measures the change in heart rate from lying to standing, used to assess autonomic nervous system balance and recovery status. An exaggerated or blunted response can indicate fatigue or overtraining.
formulas.formula: Comparison of HR (lying) vs. HR (standing after 1-2 minutes).
formulas.notes: A consistent increase in standing HR compared to baseline can suggest fatigue or sympathetic overactivity. Not a single formula, but a comparative assessment.

formulas.name: Sleep Duration
formulas.description: The total time spent sleeping. Optimal sleep duration is a range, with 'minimal' required hours for health and 'maximal' beneficial hours.
formulas.formula: Measured directly (e.g., from sleep trackers, self-report).
formulas.notes: Adequate sleep is crucial for recovery, performance, and overall health. Not a formula, but a vital metric. Recommendations often suggest 7-9 hours as an optimal range, with values below this being 'minimal' and potentially detrimental.

formulas.name: Wellness Score (Subjective)
formulas.description: A composite score derived from subjective ratings of various wellness parameters (e.g., sleep quality, muscle soreness, stress levels, mood). The goal is to maximize this score.
formulas.formula: Typically a sum or average of individual subjective ratings (e.g., 1-5 scale for each parameter).
formulas.notes: Used to monitor an athlete's subjective response to training and identify signs of overreaching or under-recovery. Not a rigid formula, but a common practice. A 'minimal' score would indicate poor well-being.

formulas.name: Work Done (Mechanical)
formulas.description: The amount of energy transferred by a force acting over a distance. Can refer to maximal work performed.

variables.name: Distance
variables.description: Distance over which the force is applied

formulas.notes: Used to quantify the mechanical output of movements like lifting, jumping, or pushing. 'Maximal work' refers to the highest amount of work performed in a given task.

formulas.name: Ground Reaction Force (GRF)
formulas.description: The force exerted by the ground on a body in contact with it. Key for analyzing locomotion and jump mechanics. Often analyzed for peak (maximal) force.
formulas.formula: Measured directly using force plates. Often analyzed for peak force, average force, and impulse.
formulas.notes: Provides insight into force production, absorption, and stability during movement. Not a formula, but a critical measured parameter. 'Maximal GRF' is the peak force exerted during a movement.

formulas.name: Efficiency (Mechanical)
formulas.description: The ratio of mechanical work output to metabolic energy input, indicating how effectively energy is converted into movement. The goal is to maximize efficiency and minimize energy waste.
formulas.notes: Higher efficiency means less energy is wasted. Requires sophisticated measurement of both mechanical work and metabolic cost. 'Minimal' energy input for a given output signifies high efficiency.

formulas.name: Joint Angles
formulas.description: Measurement of the angle at a specific joint during movement, used to analyze technique and range of motion. Can identify maximal or minimal angles achieved.
formulas.formula: Measured using goniometers, inclinometers, or motion capture systems.
formulas.notes: Crucial for assessing movement patterns, identifying limitations, and optimizing technique. For example, 'maximal knee flexion' during a squat.

formulas.name: Center of Mass (COM) Displacement/Velocity
formulas.description: Tracking the position and movement of the body's center of mass, essential for analyzing balance, posture, and dynamic movements.
formulas.formula: Calculated from kinematic data (e.g., motion capture) or force plate data.

variables.name: COM Velocity
variables.description: Rate of change of COM position

formulas.notes: Provides insight into overall body control and movement strategy. Can identify 'maximal' displacement or velocity during a movement.

formulas.name: Ground Contact Time (GCT) & Flight Time (FT)
formulas.description: For running and jumping, GCT is the time the foot is on the ground, and FT is the time spent in the air. Optimizing these is key for performance.
formulas.formula: Measured using force plates, timing gates, or specialized sensors.

variables.name: Ground Contact Time
variables.description: Time foot is on the ground (minimal desired for speed)

variables.name: Flight Time
variables.description: Time spent in the air (maximal desired for jump height)

formulas.notes: Shorter GCT and longer FT are generally indicative of more powerful and efficient running/jumping. These are 'minimal' and 'maximal' targets respectively.

formulas.name: Fitness Index (e.g., from Step Test)
formulas.description: A score derived from a submaximal exercise test (e.g., 3-minute step test) to estimate cardiovascular fitness.
formulas.formula: $$Fitness Index = \frac{Duration of Exercise (seconds) \times 100}{2 \times Sum of Recovery Pulse Counts}$$

variables.name: Sum of Recovery Pulse Counts
variables.description: Sum of heart rate counts at specific intervals during recovery

formulas.notes: Higher index indicates better fitness. Many variations of step tests and their formulas exist.

formulas.name: Work-to-Rest Ratio
formulas.description: The ratio of the duration of work (exercise) to the duration of rest in an interval training session.
formulas.notes: Crucial for designing interval training sessions to target specific energy systems (e.g., 1:1 for aerobic power, 1:3+ for anaerobic power).

formulas.name: Periodization Load Calculation (Conceptual)
formulas.description: The systematic planning of training to maximize performance at specific times, involving manipulation of training volume, intensity, and frequency across cycles. This is more of a programming strategy than a single formula.
formulas.formula: Involves calculating and adjusting ATL, CTL, TSB, and ACWR over macrocycles, mesocycles, and microcycles.

variables.name: Training Load Progression
variables.description: Planned increase/decrease in load over time

variables.name: Tapering Strategy
variables.description: Planned reduction in load to maximize freshness for competition ('minimal' load before peak)

formulas.notes: While specific formulas are used for components (like ATL/CTL), periodization itself is a complex planning process, not a single calculation. It involves managing the 'maximal' and 'minimal' training loads strategically.

NutritionFormulas.subType: Basis Metabolische Snelheid (BMS) & Totaal Dagelijks Energieverbruik (TDEV)

formules.naam: Basis Metabolische Snelheid (BMS) - Mifflin-St Jeor Formule
formules.beschrijving: Schat het aantal calorieën dat het lichaam in rust verbrandt om basale fysiologische functies te onderhouden. Dit is de 'minimale' energiebehoefte voor overleving.
formules.formule: Voor Mannen: $$BMS = (10 \times Gewicht_{kg}) + (6.25 \times Lengte_{cm}) - (5 \times Leeftijd_{jaren}) + 5$$ Voor Vrouwen: $$BMS = (10 \times Gewicht_{kg}) + (6.25 \times Lengte_{cm}) - (5 \times Leeftijd_{jaren}) - 161$$
formules.notities: Wordt beschouwd als een van de meest nauwkeurige voorspellende vergelijkingen voor BMS. Andere formules bestaan (bijv. Harris-Benedict). Dit vertegenwoordigt de 'minimale' caloriebehoefte in rust.

formules.beschrijving: Schat het totale aantal calorieën dat op een dag wordt verbrand, inclusief BMS en fysieke activiteit. Dit kan de 'maximale' energiebehoefte vertegenwoordigen, afhankelijk van het activiteitsniveau.

variabelen.beschrijving: Vermenigvuldigingsfactor gebaseerd op activiteitsniveau (bijv. Zittend: 1.2, Licht actief: 1.375, Matig actief: 1.55, Zeer actief: 1.725, Extra actief: 1.9)

formules.notities: Wordt gebruikt om de calorie-inname te bepalen voor gewichtsbehoud, -verlies of -toename.

formules.beschrijving: Het verschil tussen de geconsumeerde en verbruikte calorieën, wat de gewichtsverandering bepaalt. Een 'tekort' is een negatieve waarde, een 'overschot' is positief.
formules.notities: Een tekort leidt tot gewichtsverlies, een overschot tot gewichtstoename. Ongeveer 7700 calorieën = 1 kg lichaamsvet.

NutritionFormulas.subType: Verdeling van Eiwitten, Koolhydraten en Vetten

formules.beschrijving: Berekent de doelgrammen van een specifiek macronutriënt op basis van de totale calorie-inname en het gewenste percentage. Kan worden gebruikt om 'minimale' of 'maximale' inname voor specifieke doelen te bepalen.

variabelen.beschrijving: Gewenst percentage calorieën van dat macronutriënt (bijv. 0.30 voor 30%)
Calorische waarde per gram (Eiwit: 4 kcal/g, Koolhydraten: 4 kcal/g, Vet: 9 kcal/g)

formules.notities: Gebruikt voor nauwkeurige dieetplanning om fitnessdoelen te ondersteunen. Bijvoorbeeld, een 'minimale' eiwitinname kan 0.8g/kg lichaamsgewicht zijn, terwijl een 'maximale' 2.2g/kg of meer kan zijn voor spiergroei.

formules.beschrijving: Berekent de aanbevolen dagelijkse eiwitinname op basis van lichaamsgewicht, vaak uitgedrukt in grammen per kilogram lichaamsgewicht.

variabelen.beschrijving: Aanbevolen eiwit per kg lichaamsgewicht (bijv. 0.8 voor algemeen, 1.6-2.2 voor sporters)

formules.notities: De eiwitfactor varieert sterk afhankelijk van activiteitsniveau, leeftijd en doelen (bijv. spiergroei, gewichtsverlies).

formules.beschrijving: Berekent de aanbevolen dagelijkse koolhydraatinname op basis van lichaamsgewicht, vaak uitgedrukt in grammen per kilogram lichaamsgewicht, vooral voor sporters.

variabelen.beschrijving: Aanbevolen koolhydraat per kg lichaamsgewicht (bijv. 3-10 voor sporters, afhankelijk van intensiteit)

formules.notities: De behoefte aan koolhydraten is sterk afhankelijk van de trainingsintensiteit en duur. Hogere factoren voor duursporters.

formules.beschrijving: Berekent de aanbevolen dagelijkse vetinname op basis van lichaamsgewicht, vaak uitgedrukt in grammen per kilogram lichaamsgewicht.
formules.notities: Vetinname is cruciaal voor hormoonproductie en algehele gezondheid. Vaak uitgedrukt als een percentage van de totale calorieën (bijv. 20-35%).

formules.naam: Aanbevolen Dagelijkse Hoeveelheden (ADH) / Dietary Reference Intakes (DRIs)
formules.beschrijving: Vastgestelde waarden voor de inname van vitaminen en mineralen om tekorten te voorkomen en optimale gezondheid te ondersteunen. Dit zijn 'minimale' tot 'optimale' innamehoeveelheden.
formules.formule: Geen specifieke formule; dit zijn vastgestelde referentiewaarden per nutriënt, variërend per leeftijd, geslacht, zwangerschap/lactatie, en activiteitsniveau.

variabelen.beschrijving: Specifieke vitamine of mineraal (bijv. Vitamine C, IJzer, Calcium)

formules.notities: Deze waarden worden gepubliceerd door nationale en internationale gezondheidsorganisaties (bijv. Gezondheidsraad in Nederland, USDA in VS). Overschrijding van de 'maximale' toelaatbare inname (Tolerable Upper Intake Levels - ULs) kan toxiciteit veroorzaken.

formules.beschrijving: Een maat voor de hoeveelheid nutriënten per calorie in een voedingsmiddel, om voedingsmiddelen te identificeren die veel nutriënten leveren met relatief weinig calorieën.

variabelen.beschrijving: Percentage van de aanbevolen dagelijkse hoeveelheid van een specifiek nutriënt in een portie

formules.notities: Hogere scores duiden op een hogere nutriëntdichtheid. Helpt bij het kiezen van voedingsmiddelen die 'maximaal' nutriënten leveren voor 'minimale' calorieën.

formules.beschrijving: De procentuele verdeling van calorieën over eiwitten, koolhydraten en vetten in een dieetplan.
formules.notities: Gangbare verhoudingen variëren sterk (bijv. 30/40/30 voor gebalanceerd, 20/50/30 voor duursporters, 40/30/30 voor gewichtsverlies/spierbehoud). Dit is een 'maximale' of 'minimale' focus op bepaalde macronutriënten.

formules.beschrijving: De Glycemische Index (GI) meet hoe snel koolhydraten in een voedingsmiddel de bloedsuikerspiegel verhogen. De Glycemische Lading (GL) houdt rekening met zowel de GI als de portiegrootte.
formules.notities: Lage GI/GL voedingsmiddelen zorgen voor een stabielere bloedsuikerspiegel. Belangrijk voor diabetesmanagement en duurprestaties. De 'minimale' of 'maximale' impact op de bloedsuikerspiegel.

formules.beschrijving: De aanbevolen dagelijkse inname van vezels voor darmgezondheid en verzadiging.
formules.formule: Geen specifieke formule; aanbevelingen zijn vaak in grammen per dag (bijv. 25-30g/dag voor volwassenen).
formules.notities: Een 'minimale' inname is cruciaal voor gezondheid, terwijl een 'maximale' inname (te veel) spijsverteringsproblemen kan veroorzaken.

formules.beschrijving: Een subjectieve, maar veelgebruikte methode om de hydratatiestatus te beoordelen op basis van de kleur van de urine. Donkere urine duidt op 'minimale' hydratatie.
formules.notities: Lichtere kleuren (1-3) duiden op goede hydratatie, donkere kleuren (4+) op uitdroging. Dit is een snelle visuele indicator, geen analytische formule.

formules.beschrijving: Schatting van de dagelijkse waterbehoefte, afhankelijk van lichaamsgewicht en activiteitsniveau.
formules.formule: $$Waterbehoefte (L) = Lichaamsgewicht (kg) \times 0.03$$ (basisrichtlijn) + extra voor activiteit en omgevingsfactoren
formules.notities: Dit is een basisrichtlijn; individuele behoeften variëren sterk. Sporters en mensen in warme klimaten hebben een 'maximale' behoefte.

formules.description: Essentieel voor spiergroei en -herstel, enzymen, hormonen en immuunfunctie.
formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'bouwstenen' voor algoritme-ontwikkeling en -onderhoud; essentieel voor de integriteit en reparatie van het systeem, en de constructie van nieuwe modules.

formules.description: Primaire energiebron voor het lichaam en de hersenen.

recommendations.high_intensity_exercise: 5-10 gram per kg lichaamsgewicht (afhankelijk van duur en intensiteit)

formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'brandstof' voor computationele processen; de primaire energiebron voor het uitvoeren van instructies en het verwerken van data.

formules.description: Essentieel voor hormoonproductie, vitamine-absorptie, celmembranen en energiereserves.
formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'lange-termijn opslag' en 'structurele componenten' van het algoritme; cruciaal voor stabiliteit, communicatie tussen modules en reserve-energie.

formules.description: Organische verbindingen nodig in kleine hoeveelheden voor diverse lichaamsfuncties.
formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'co-factoren' of 'configuratieparameters' die kleine, maar cruciale, aanpassingen mogelijk maken voor de optimale werking van specifieke subroutines of modules.

formules.description: Anorganische elementen nodig voor botten, tanden, zenuwfunctie, vloeistofbalans, etc.
formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'essentiële bibliotheken' of 'frameworks' die de fundamentele functionaliteit van het algoritme ondersteunen, van data-overdracht tot structurele integriteit.

formules.description: Data over de precieze voedingswaarde van duizenden voedingsmiddelen.
formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'referentietabellen' en 'lookup-tabellen' die het algoritme gebruikt om contextuele informatie over zijn 'inputs' (voeding) te begrijpen.

formules.description: Referentiewaarden voor voedingsstoffen voor gezonde populaties.
categories: Aanbevolen Dagelijkse Hoeveelheid (ADH): Gemiddelde dagelijkse inname die voldoende is voor bijna alle gezonde individuen.
Adequate Inname (AI): Gebruikt wanneer ADH niet kan worden vastgesteld, gebaseerd op waarnemingen van gezonde mensen.
Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): Maximale dagelijkse inname die waarschijnlijk geen nadelige gezondheidseffecten veroorzaakt.
formules.relevance_human_algorithm: De 'veiligheidsprotocollen' en 'optimale configuratielimieten' voor de input van het algoritme, om zowel functionaliteit als 'gezondheid' te garanderen.
